Name: Autorennen wie noch nie
Description:
Objective: Be the first to finish

'Roll and Move' game with some modifications.
Of course, there are some fields to accelerate or decelerate your car (your bride is waiting for you, you have to make a phone call...), but using your three dice ==> only '1' and '5' are giving you the speed you need. It's up to your choice - if you gain a 1 or 5, to roll the remaining 2 dice again for all or nothing (early 'Can't Stop).

Remarks:
Due to (sometimes) small changes it's very difficult to track versions and define the publishing date of the first edition;
there are (at least) 3 different Gräfe editions and from 1970 the Spika one; if you check the boards you can detect a (confused?) numbering system - see images. 
Some Sellers (e.g. on ebay) declare a publishing date mid 1935, but to my knowlegde those 'Bikini maids', printed on the early edition were not permitted/accepted by National Socialists. But even more confusing - one auction shows hand written notes (to replace (lost) rules) in Sütterlin writing.
 - feedback is highly appreciated -

Name: Woodland Race
Description:
Relive the glorious moments of the epic race between Hare and Tortoise! Several decades ago, Hare suffered a crushing defeat against a determined Tortoise. This painful affair threw disgrace and dishonour onto the Hare's clan and it would take many generations for the affront to be forgotten. Forgotten, did I say? Never! Hare is determined to restore his family's honor – but Tortoise will not give up without a fight.

Woodland Race is an asymmetrical race game in which audacity and strategy will be your best assets! The players build the track over successive rounds, sometimes helping Hare and sometimes helping Tortoise. Hare is fleet of foot but will often need to stop for a rest, whilst Tortoise is slow but moves with purpose. Many obstacles arise on the way, and who will win is up to you...

Name: Monopoly: Harley-Davidson Authorized Edition
Description:
From the back of the box

There is a new major rally... and you've hit the highway. Two American Icons, The Monopoly Brand and Harley-Davidson, have joined forces to create the most popular board game on two wheels. Monopoly, the world's most popular board game, proudly introduces a game designed exclusively for the Harley-Davidson enthusiast.

Buy, sell and trade the great motorcycles, engines, rallies and all that makes the Harley-Davidson lifestyle what it is! Hop on your Electra Glide Standard or Heritage Springer, but be sure to ride clear of your opponent's properties--landing on the wrong space could cost you big!

Game includes: Game Board, Property Cards, Money & Banker's Tray, 2 Dice, Chance Cards, Community Chest Cards, Package of 32 Garages, Package of 12 Dealerships, & 8 Pewter Custom Game Tokens.

Name: Buchstabengitter
Description:
Buchstabengitter is a word-searching game.

The game comes with 160 different word search puzzles, like the ones that appear in the newspaper. However, players will search for words simultaneously. Each round, a die is rolled, which indicates how many words must be found. Then, that number of cards is drawn; there is a word on each card.

Now, the players have to search for the words in the puzzle and mark them on their sheet. The round ends when a player has found all the words. Then, each player gains one point for each word found. The player that has gained the most points after four rounds wins the game.

The puzzles do not only contain each German word, but also the English translation, which makes it possible to use this game to learn English.

Name: Warhammer: Invasion – City of Winter
Description:
Game description from the publisher:

No one is safe from the schemes the Dark Elves hatch in their City of Winter. With three copies each of 20 unique cards, half of which support the Dark Elves and their evil schemes, City of Winter is an invaluable Battle Pack for players looking to harness the Dark Elves and their fury.

Additionally, all the factions gain exciting new tactics cards that can return to the deck after they are played. The fifth Battle Pack in "The Capital Cycle" for Warhammer: Invasion The Card Game, City of Winter presents dramatic new deck-building options for the Dark Elves and other factions with 60 new cards (three copies each of 20 different cards).
Families: Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: Warhammer Invasion – Living Card Game

Name: Dust Tactics: Schwer-Sturmgrenadiere Command Squad – "Heavy Kommandotrupp"
Description:
Game description from the publisher:

As the battles of Dust Tactics intensify, NCO Command Squads inspire their allies to tremendous feats with their new special abilities. Marching to the front lines in their protective battle suits, the Axis Heavy Kommandotrupp withstand enemy small arms fire as they call in artillery strikes, repair walkers and send them back into battle, or boost soldiers with powerful, untested chemicals. These powerful squads provide clear direction for other troops and offer players tremendous army-building flexibility.

Dust Tactics: "Heavy Kommandotrupp" - Schwer-Sturmgrenadiere Command Squad includes a unit card and three distinct miniatures.

Name: Dust Tactics: Heavy Rangers Command Squad – "Corps Officers"
Description:
Game description from the publisher:

As the battles of Dust Tactics intensify, NCO Command Squads inspire their allies to tremendous feats with their new special abilities. Marching to the front lines in their protective battle suits, the Allied Corps Officers withstand enemy small arms fire as they call in artillery strikes, repair walkers and send them back into battle, or boost soldiers with powerful, untested chemicals. These powerful squads provide clear direction for other troops and offer players tremendous army-building flexibility.

Dust Tactics: "Corps Officers" - Heavy Rangers Command Squad includes a unit card and three distinct miniatures.

Name: Notch
Description: Notch - A Tumbledum dice game from REMCO from 1955. This is a very simple game where you turn a tumbler over. That tumbler has dice in it which results in your roll for the turn. You can land on various spaces on a board (that board is actually a rolled up piece of plastic that has to be opened and flattened before you can play) There are go back spaces and there are GET NOTCHES spaces for capturing outlaws. When you reach the finish space the one with the most notches wins the game.

Name: Vehicles
Description:
Vehicles is a quick, challenging worker placement game.  Unlike other worker placement games which can take two or more hours to play, Vehicles is designed to take about 20 minutes per player.  That means a game usually lasts about an hour and a half or less.  It's also quick to set up and get going.

Each of your vehicles is a worker in this game and each has its own abilities.  Move your Car to a land space to buy a part, or move your boat to the salvage where your car cannot reach.  You can build additional worker vehicles.  Will you build the fast rocket that always goes first but cannot carry cargo, or the sneaky submarine that can share a space with another vehicle?

Vehicles was created for The Game Crafter's first game design contest.

Name: Call Up Put Down
Description:
Call Up Put Down is a boardgame from Trading Pursuits Pty Ltd, a trading education company.

The objective of the game is to earn $1,000,000 from trading options. They begin with a starting capital (usually $10,000), and then make decisions whether to buy / sell Call options or Put options based on the charts viewed on the DVD.

The DVD contains 50 sets of charts, and only one chart is viewed at a time (by selecting a card that contains numbers 1 to 50 at random). The players make their decisions, and then moves to the next screen of the trade by using the DVD controls. When it reaches the last day to trade, all players must sell their options, and compute the final balance, which is recorded on the Trading Diary.

The board contains a track showing amounts from $0 to $1,000,000, and player's tokens move forward or back on the track depending on their balance. The first player who reaches $1,000,000 wins.

Components:
- 1 board with a dollar-sign track
- 6 tokens
- trading diary pads to record trades
- calculation pads to record stop-loss and profit targets
- strategy cards depicting signals when to buy/sell call/put options
- 2 DVDs (an Options informative DVD and a Trades DVD)
- game manual
- pencils

Name: Electric Speedway
Description:
A battery operated British game. In the 1930's, Speedway was a tremendously popular sport so companies were quite keen to add a Speedway game to their portfolio.

This is a game of chance, no skill required at all. The board has a wheel with six different coloured speedway bikes on it. Players are invited to put their bets on to a Roulette-like board. You could play for real money or buttons. When all the bets are placed, you flick a switch and the wheel will spin. As each bike goes past a connection, their colour light flashes on, so with a fast spinning wheel, the lights all flash, adding to the excitement. When the wheel stops, there will be one light on and that is the race winner. Winning punters collect their bets and another race can start. The winner must be the one who has the most money when the game ends.

Name: Dan Dare's Race in Space
Description:
This is a simple roll and move game. If you land on an orange square you must obey the instructions. The best squares allow you to take shortcuts. The first to get to the end of the track, wins.

Dan Dare was a hero from boy's comics, making his debut in the Eagle comic in 1950. He was drawn by Frank Hampson. The character was an immediate hit and there was even a weekly serial transmitted on Radio Luxembourg.

Name: Mickey Mouse Quoits
Description: An indoor quoits game. You thow your rings, with the aim of getting them to settle on to a hook and you score points for every success. The first to reach a pre-set number of points, wins. Or, it can be ended after a pre-set time limit and then the player with the most points, wins.
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Robin Hood

Name: Dan Dare Shooting Game
Description:
Dan Dare Shooting game by Chad Valley is a target game with the board featuring several aliens advancing. The gun, is a spring loaded Pop gun with corks. Object of the game is to be the first to knock out the alien targets.

During the early 1950's the Comic Hero Dan Dare spurred several similar target games that can easily be confused. Featured on this link is Chad Valley's version with the simple title "Dan Dare Shooting" game. Chad Valley also produced another Target Game called "Dan Dare Big Game Hunt on Venus".

Listed elsewhere on BGG is a Dan Dare Target game by the company Glevum with a very similar title called "Dan Dare Space Shooting".

Name: Stop and Go!
Description: A simple roll and move game. The board represents central London, with lots of crossroads, so your route might be diverted if you land on the wrong square. Nice metal playing pieces.

Name: Wings of Glory: WW1 Special Packs
Description:
The first WW1 products for Wings of Glory are two extra-large models: the WW1 bombers Caproni CA.3 and Gotha G.V. Each Wings of Glory: WW1 Special Pack contains one painted and assembled 1/144 model with the flight stand and the maneuvre cards related to that airplane, the special rules leaflet, the plane consolle, and counters required to play with these models. The WWI bombers are featured in two different color schemes each.

Wings of War players can add these new models and their rules to the game without any problem.

Wings of Glory WWI planes are 100% compatible with Wings of War, using the same scale, base-fittings and pegs.

Reimplements: 

    Wings of War: Flight of the Giants
    Wings of War: Deluxe Set
    Wings of War: Miniatures


See Also:

    Wings of Glory: WW2 Starter Set

Name: Jack Hobbs Table Cricket
Description:
An action cricket game.

One player is the batsman, the other the bowler. The two, rather scary, figures have handles so that their arm can be pulled back and then released forward. The bowler's arm will launch a ball at the batsman. He, in reply, will try to swing his bat and connect with the ball.
The player who scores the most runs (i.e. hits) will win.

Sir John Berry "Jack" Hobbs (1882 - 1963) is widely regarded as one of the best opening batsmen of all time

Name: Recon...by Fire: Issue 4
Description:
Issue 4 of Heat of Battle's ASL magazine.

The magazine has 44 pages, contains 176 vehicle counters for ASL, 14 new scenarios for ASL, a new Deluxe ASL map (named BF1), a sheet with Deluxe ASL Rubble Overlays, and an APC Player Aid, as well as various articles about ASL.

From the table of contents:

Notes from the Command Post - Editoral
German use of Soviet Tanks - Red Steel
Rules Analyses - Slopes in ASL
Designer's Notes - Onslaught to Orsha
Chow in ASL - The German Gulasch Kanone
Scenario Analysis - RBF-17 Hot Spot
Heat of Battle Errata - HOB Errata and Q&A

The following scenarios for ASL are included:
RBF39: THEY REALLY KNOW HOW TO DIE; 14 September 1939; Brochow-Solchaczew, Poland
RBF40: KING'S GAMBIT; 9 April, 1940; Copenhagen, Denmark
RBF41: VATUTIN'S RIGHT HOOK; 14 July, 1941; Sol'sty, Russia
RBF42: KEYSTONE BEFORE MOSCOW; 26 November, 1941; Istra, Russia
RBF43: BLOOD FACTORY; 24 October, 1942; Stalingrad, Russia
RBF44: STEELINGRAD; 26 October, 1942; Stalingrad, Russia
RBF45: LONE BRIDGE OVER THE VOLGA; 14 October, 1941; Kalinin, Russia
RBF46: TEMPEST AT TOMBE; 1 July, 1943; Tombe Village, New Georgia, Solomon Islands
RBF47: SPLITTING THE SEAM; 30 July, 1944; Sept-Vents, France
RBF48: THE NARROW FRONT; 13 October, 1944; Würselen, Germany
RBF49: FROM BAD TO WÜRSELEN; 15 October, 1944; Würselen, Germany
RBF50: A PERFECT MATCH; 25 December, 1944; Foy-Notre Dame, Belgium
RBF51: FINAL GLORY; 3 May, 1945; Lampertswalde, Germany
RBF52: CHOU EN-LAI'S PROMISE; 6 October, 1945; Along the Tientsin-Peiping Road, China

Name: Lords of Cricket
Description:
An Australian cricket board game. It takes into account Test, One Day, Twenty20 and even back yard cricket.
The game is designed to replicate game conditions including real life statistics and score keeping. Lords of Cricket is fun and educational for kids, improving their maths skills while teaching them the fundamentals of cricket. The box says 'Great for players of all ages from 7 to 107' so any of you 108 year old cricket game fans are out of luck.

The Lords of Cricket playing board is divided into four parts, one for each of the different versions of a game of cricket. The board consists of six circles, each one representing the six balls in an over. Each game of Lords of Cricket is played with cricket ball-shaped cards, each designed to imitate different formats of the game of cricket.
Red cards are for Test cricket 
White cards are for One Day International and Back Yard cricket 
Yellow cards are used for Twenty-20 cricket 
There are four dice 
White - Ball Dice - numbered from 1 to 6 representing the number of the ball in the over 
Yellow - Appeal Dice - used to determine the type of appeal 
Red - Out Dice - used to determine how a batsman is out 
Black - Reverse Decision Dice - used to reverse an Appeal decision

Name: TF22
Description:
In the 22nd century, the white mineral has become one of the most important resources. The material is a catalyst that enables many new production processes. Each player is a pilot of one of his company’s spacecraft, on the way to the planet GH-328 in the Panajay system. This undeveloped planet has large deposits of the white mineral.

The goal of each player in TF22 is to leave the planet with as much white mineral and as many units as possible. At the start of the game, each player lands on the planet with a landing craft and several units: a production unit, transporters, and combat units. The production unit can be used to create new units by consuming white mineral. The transports can be used to gather ore and bring it to the landing craft (though they can also carry some of the other units). The combat units can be used to capture or destroy enemy units. Each turn, players receive a number of action points to perform these actions.

Players should not only watch out for the units of other players. They also need to keep an eye on the tide. This can change every round. Areas that were previously accessible only by naval units may suddenly become accessible to land units instead, and vice versa.

Name: Canada at War #1
Description:
A collection of six scenarios for Advanced Squad Leader, featuring Canadian units during World War II:

MLR1: HANA-SAKU; 19 December 1941; Mt. Butler, Hong Kong Island
MLR2: TROTEVAL FARM; 24 July 1944; Near Verrieres, Normandy, France
MLR3: MOOSHOF MELEE; 26 February 1945; Mooshof, Germany
MLR4: SNEAK ATTACK; 16 April 1945; The Village of Sneek, Holland
MLR5: THIRD TIME LUCKY; 1 August 1944; St. Martin-de-Fontenay, France
MLR6: GRENADE AND BAYONET; 1 March 1945; The Siegfried Line on the western edge of the Hochwald Forest, Germany

Name: Critical Hit! - Volume 7, No. 3
Description:
Volume 7, No. 3 of Critical Hit's ASL magazine, containing articles, scenarios and a historical map (Pointe du Hoc) for Advanced Squad Leader.

The following articles are included:
- Scenario Analysis: Akrotiri Gone Awry (a scenario from this issue)
- Küstenjäger: German Coastal Commandos in ASL
- Incidents with the 7th: A first-hand account of British combat on the battlefields of Normandy in 1944
- Tigers to the Front: A review of the scenario pack
- Busting the Bocage: A review of the ASL module

The following scenarios are included (BtB scenarios are played on the enclosed historical map):
BtB#1: NO NEED FOR ORDERS; 6 June 1944; Pointe du Hoc, France
BtB#2: SHRAPNEL MOTIVATION; 6 June 1944; Pointe du Hoc, France
BtB#3: A FUTILE HOUR; 6 June 1944; Pointe du Hoc, France
BtB#4: ROUT THE KRAUT; 6 June 1944; Pointe du Hoc, France
BtB#5; WALKING WOUNDED; 6 June 1944; Pointe du Hoc, France
BtB#6: FROM OMAHA WITH LOVE; 8 June 1944; Pointe du Hoc, France
CH#170: BRIDEGROOMS  OF DEATH; 14 August 1936, Badajoz, Spain
CH#171: INTERNACIONALE FOLLIES; 14 December 1936, Boadilla, Spain
CH#172: WINTER BLUES; 19 March 1942; North of Novgorod, Russia
CH#173: 'BITCHES' ON THE BEACH; 11 August 1945; Sakhalin Island
CH#174: SETTLING AN OLD SCORE; 17 August 1945; Sakhalin Island
CH#175: ESCAPE HATCH; 24 June 1941; Grodno, Russia
CH#176: TOUCHDOWN!; 28 May 1940; Abbeville, France
CH#177: AKROTIRI GONE AWRY; 20 May 1941; Akrotiri Peninsula, Crete
CH#178: CROCODILE HUNT; 8 February 1945; Frasselt, Germany
CH#179: ACROSS THE BEREZINA; 9 July 1941; near Osipovitchi, Russia
CH#180: THE RUINS OF SILLEGNY; 19 September 1944; Sillegny, France
CH#181: THUNDER AT SEELOW; 16 April 1945; Seelow, Germany

Name: Asara: Die Gaben des Kalifen
Description:
Asara: Die Gaben des Kalifen (The Caliph's Gifts), an expansion included in the 2011 Wolfgang Kramer Almanach published by Spielbox, can be used with both the basic and advanced Asara game.

For the basic game, five locations on the board (such as the middle section of the window and the +8 space of the bank) are marked with treasure chest markers. One card from a deck of 20 is placed face-up next to each space. Whenever a player goes to one of these spaces with a buyer, he takes the card, and executes the action shown on the card: acquire 4-6 gold, buy one tower tile of the depicted type (top, middle or bottom), earn two prestige points, or choose one buyer from the deck. At the end of each year, each location receives a new card (in addition to the ones still there).

In the advanced game, one of the spaces in the "House of the Lighted Windows" is marked with a treasure chest marker as well, and also receives cards with bonus actions. In addition, four cards are added to the deck which force a player to buy a lighted window at a cost of four gold when he visits the space.

Name: So You Want to Teach?
Description:
So You Want to Teach is a card driven game for two to four players on the issues and events many beginning teachers must deal with in the course of becoming a professional educator. The game is meant to serve as an entertaining vehicle by which students and practitioners in education can discuss and evaluate issues, trends, as well as their individual motivations, in K-12 education.

Each “turn” players deal five cards and then take turns drawing a card from those that remain. The drawn card’s Event is revealed/ read aloud to the others after which players can bid for the event by playing cards from their deck. The winner of the bidding will then take procession of the card, adding it to their “Portfolio”. A card that is not claimed will go into the discard pile. Instead of drawing a card a player can also “Pass” and exchange any or all of the cards in their hand for new cards from the deck, or to “cash in” the point values of their cards to advance their “Epistemology, Axiology or Political” track markers. Players can also exchange cards in their deck for “Mentor” cards that can be used for various game functions.

The goal of each player is to acquire a portfolio of Challenge and Opportunity event cards, as well as a number of sufficient Axiology, Epistemology and Political points to pass the Praxis III (professional licensing) exam and win the game. It is possible for all, some or none of the players to win the game by the last turn.

So you want to teach? Learn, discover, reflect, and enjoy!

Graphics by Bruce Yearian.

Components:

84 playing cards
4 player aid sheets
24 markers
4 pages of rules

Name: Vicious City
Description:
Los Angeles, 10th of August 1953. A ceiling fan rotates awkwardly, slowly pushing stale air around an ill lit office. Near a darkened window a lonely detective sits in a rickety old chair, feet on a desk, reading a police report. A couple of filing cabinets, a coat rack with a fedora, a bottle of bourbon and an ashtray overflowing with cigarette butts complete the scene. "Someone needs to get to the bottom of this case, it sure as hell won't solve itself!"

Vicious City is a narrative deduction game for 2-5 investigators. A crime has been committed and the players are tasked with solving the case, attempting to gain a conviction against one guilty suspect whilst ensuring another suspect, who they know is innocent, is absolved.

When the last evidence token is drawn from the bag the current round is completed and the case is resolved. Players are awarded victory points based on the outcome of the case and the player who scores the highest victory point total wins the game.

Name: Fighting Eagles: Air Battles of 1918
Description:
Fighting Eagles uses a simple game system to simulate the air battles of 1918 fought between the American and German air forces. Based on Rohrbaugh's Showtime Hanoi design, players will play head-to-head matches pitting several Allied aircraft vs. their German counterparts.

Allied player wins the game if their German target is destroyed and more German aircraft are destroyed than Allied. Any other result is a German win. If Red Baron (Fokker Dr1) is shot down or leaves the map the best the German can do is tie.

In addition the game will include two historical scenarios: Red Baron's Last Flight and Frank Luke's Last Flight and several variants including additional missions of bombing & balloon busting.

Players will need a standard deck of cards and one six-sided die (D6) to play the game.

Each copy of Fighting Eagles is composed of the following:


     One set of 40 die cut counters
     One 8.5 by 11 map with the Turn Record Track
     A set of rules

Name: Jogo Rápido
Description: Players roll a colored die and pick a card of the appropriate color. Then they have to build whatever is shown on the card, as fast as possible. The first to finish gets to pick first one VP chip - but there is some luck involved in getting the better chips.

Name: Jogo da Vida Feliz
Description: A very different version of The Game of Life, where money matters very little - in fact, the player with most happiness chips is the winner at the end!

Name: Detetive Júnior Turma da Mônica
Description: Based on the Detetive (Cluedo) I.P. but with very different mechanics. Players have to discover who is the secret character, based on four characteristics: male/female, child/adult, dark hair/light hair, with hat/without hat. Simple rules, aimed at children.
Families: Game: Cluedo / Clue (Parker Brothers, et al)

Name: Banco Imobiliário Júnior
Description: Based on Banco Imobiliário (Monopoly), but with simpler rules and with a shorter playing time. Mainly, properties here are grouped by colors and symbols - and a player can build whenever he has a complete set of colors *or* a complete set of symbols.

Name: GBO Hawai'i
Description:
Produced by www.GreenBusinessOwner.com, this game makes sustainability come to life in a fun, interactive way. Players are investors looking to make more than just financial returns by helping local entrepreneurs in Hawai'i develop sustainability-oriented businesses like organic farms, geothermal plants, green building companies, solar installers, and bike shops. The game is ideal for those who are interested in sustainability as a better way to do business, and can be played by 2-4 players ages 13+. It's also a great learning tool, and the parent company has produced free downloadable lesson planning materials for teachers! Check out www.GBOHawaii.com for more info on that.

The game consists of a beautiful board with the map of Hawai'i, several decks of playing cards used in the game, a green business property deck of businesses you can invest in, dice, player pieces, and a stack of money.

The game is set in Hawai'i, and players act as impact investors. Their goal is to start businesses that have a triple bottom line effect: make money, create good paying green jobs, and deal with three main environmental challenges of energy, food, and waste. To establish businesses, players must obtain certain resources like human resources (entrepreneurs, green collar workers, and the wild card--green MBA's). Some businesses require permits, mostly for larger developments and energy projects, and it's a humorous twist on permitting processes in local governments--full of possibilities and potential frustrations. Players must also navigate public policy and chance events that may or may not be helpful in achieving the goal of a sustainable economy in Hawai'i.

The player with the best Triple Bottom Line (people, planet, profit) score wins the game!

Name: Uncensored, The Party Game of Shouting Obscenities
Description:
"I've compiled the most obscene words and embellished each one with politically correct artwork for your own enjoyment. In this game each player is stamped with one of these improper words which would be totally inappropriate in almost any other situation, however I've created a game that generates an environment that turns vulgarity into a socially acceptable fun time. Win by cussing out your friends and family. The game has three intensifying rounds of play so hilarious you'll swear you never had so much fun."

"Everyone draws a card from the obscene word deck.  After everyone has shares their new lable, players take turns flipping their cards in front of them. When the card onto of your pile matches someone elses , shout their lable before they shout yours.  The loser collects both piles of cards. The first one to get of their cards is the winner.  "

Game description on kickstarter page.

Name: Legend of the Cipher: The Game of Hip-Hop
Description:
Legend of the Cipher: The Game of Hip Hop

Legend of the Cipher (LOC) is a race to the top in professional hip hop. In order to succeed, you’ll make Moves, collaborate with Allies, put on Shows, employ Crew, experiment with Venture strategies, and buy Shine. As your Hype and Cash grow, your Career will evolve with your Opportunities, and you’ll learn to count your Bars as you kick your rhymes in a cycle of Ciphers and Battles that lead to the acquisition of skills, wisdom, and respect. Strategic deckbuilding and card play gives rise to multiple lyrical Battles and Ciphers in a revolutionary game that concisely emulates the reality of hip hop today... ALL of hip hop.

Gameplay Summary

Legend of the Cipher is a deckbuilding game, where players start with a basic deck that produces Bars and Cash, which they will use to acquire Opportunity cards each turn to add to their deck. Each turn, players must also perform at Shows, using their Bars to attempt to out-rap the other players. This involves actual rapping, although one can easily play the included variant without raps. Successful raps will be rewarded with Hype, which is used to level up your rapper, in turn increasing both your hand size and production of Bars. The objective of LOC is to be the first player to level up enough to become a Legend of the Cipher.

Name: Dü-KO
Description:
From the Kickstarter entry.

The World's 1st Multiplayer Sudoku Game

"Dü-KO is like Sudoku, but only funner! Many efforts have been made to turn Sudoku into a board game, but the integrity of the puzzle always ended up being compromised. It was always a pain to setup and the truth be told not a real fun board game - with no real advantage for you the player.

So here comes Du-KO taking the concept of Sudoku to a whole new level, allowing for multi-players but still respecting the integrity of the solitaire player too. From 1- 9 players of all ages from 8 to 88 can easily and happily play Du-KO for a guaranteed good time.

The object of the game is to finish your section of the Sudoku grid first before your opponent(s). Each player takes their turn placing a peg in an open space within their designated portion of the puzzle. You'll go from clueless to competent your first game, and by your second game you'll have advanced from competent to competitive. Here's where it gets cut-throat and smokin' hot! You've been warned.

The amazing part about Du-KO is that it is self-checking! When you play, the game will tell you instantly that whether you’re wrong or right. If the peg is correct it will set all the way down, if incorrect it will remain slightly elevated and then must be removed and replayed on your next turn."

Name: Hallo-Nicki!
Description:
Objective: To earn the most shillings.

From TV series early 60's 'Nicki' (known as Noddy elsewhere)
it's a simple 'Roll and Move' game
Even some sources name 4 players only - 6 children may participate.
In the English edition there are only four car playing pieces.

Name: Jumbles
Description:
Party game that tests guests' sporting knowledge. Each guest is given a name of a sportsman, on a card but the letters spelling that name are all jumbled up. Guests are encouraged to mingle and, whilst chatting, casually ask each other if they can see their card and write down who they think the sportsman is. The one who identifies the most in the quickest time, wins.
Lots of variations of subject matter were also made by this publisher.

The games were mainly listed as being from the Dainty Series.

Name: Jumbled Proverbs
Description:
Party game. Guests are each given a card with a jumbled up proverb on it. Durind the party they can show each other their card, and if they know the correct answer, they fill in their record sheet. The person with the most right in the shortest time, wins.

Part of the publisher's 'Dainty' Series of Evening Party Games

Name: Tell-Tale Tracks
Description:
A clever party game. Each guest is given a card and all guests are encouraged to show each other their cards whilst chatting. If you know the answer, you write it on your record sheet. The guest who gets the most correct answers in the shortest time, wins.

It is clever because you only have the images of tracks (footprints and the like) to go on and some are quite subtle.

Name: Rimau
Description:
A Malaysian abstract board game for two players. One takes the role of the Tiger, who is trying to eat the Men (orang-orang) and avoid capture. The Men must corner (or otherwise immobilize) the Tiger in order to win.

The Tiger is just one token on the board, and the Tiger can only jump over (eat) rows with an odd number of Man tokens. Men can move, but before that, the Man player takes their turn placing new Man tokens down on the board. Once the pool of 22 Men (some versions call for 24) has been emptied, the Man player may freely move the Man tokens.

Rimau is an asymmetrical strategy abstract that uses an expanded Alquerque board.

Name: Dinosaur Cowboys
Description:
Dinosaur Cowboys is a fast playing (45 to 60 minutes) skirmish game of competing posses composed of up to 5 members and 1 dinosaur. Each character in the posse can be customized to fulfill a different role and purchase weapons and equipment from the many options available. Combat takes place in the futuristic landscape of the year 2285, where a supervolcano erupted and changed the course of mankind forever.

In the general the game is built around D12s and is meant to be light, thematic, and fast playing. Players build a Posse containing a Leader, 2-4 Members, and up to 1 Dinosaur, all of which benefit from some unique mechanics. Each Member has an Allegiance such as Duster or Neotechnoist which helps differentiate them (both thematically and statistically). Otherwise there are fairly standard statistics (Speed, Defense, Hitpoints, etc.) which can be customized by spending Improvement Points to really help define a role for each character. Furthermore Active and Passive Traits are selected to let characters do cool things like Crippling Shot, Speed Reload, Go For the Eyes, etc. Weapons and equipment are then purchased from a list of over 75 items ranging from laser Six-Shooters to plasma Shotguns.

A standard game takes place on a tabletop covered in terrain and uses 28mm miniatures and plastic dinosaur toys. Activation of entities is done on a model-by-model basis instead of the entire Posse at once, so the battles are very fluid with plenty of time to react to the enemy. This is especially true as Initiative is rolled at the start of each Activation "set" instead of staying the same for the whole turn.

Posses battle each other in one-off standalone games or in a linked campaign where further Improvement Points and Neodollars can be used to build and grow the group. Likewise injuries can accrue on characters that were taken out of action during an encounter. Deployment, objectives, and features can be used to add depth and variety to each battle beyond "kill everything".

The full rules are free to download and can be used with any range of miniatures. There is also a free "beginner version" (called Quickdraw) which condenses the core mechanics to under 10 pages, so players can jump into the game very easily.

Name: Auf der Eisenbahn
Description:
Objective: first on target

Simple 'Roll and Move' game with cute meeples, based 'GDR rules' for educational purposes.  Nice drawings

Name: Transformers: Heavy Metal War
Description:
"Many millions of years ago, on the planet Cybertron, life existed, but not life as we know it today. Intelligent robots that could think and feel inhabited the cities. They were called Autobots and Decepticons. But the brutal Decepticons were driven by a single goal: total domination. They set out to destroy the peace-loving Autobots, and a war between the forces of good and evil raged across Cybertron, devastating all in its path, draining the planet's once rich sources of energy. The Autobots, on the verge of extinction, battled valiantly to survive." - The Opening Narration from "More Than Meets the Eye, Part I

When an elite team of Autobots left Cybertron in search of energon, they were pursued by Megatron and his Decepticons. They crashed on Earth four million years ago and fell into a state of involuntary hibernation. Then, in 1984 they awakened, making Earth into a battlefield, with energon as the prize. Now the heroic Optimus Prime and his valiant Autobots must stop Megatron and the cruel Decepticons from plundering the Earth and fueling a war of galactic conquest.

Transformers: Heavy Metal War is a card game that allows players to command their favorite Transformers from the first two seasons of the classic 1984 cartoon show. Each player must manage their hand and deploy Transformers with a variety of powers in order to complete missions, each giving the victor a unique reward. You will not only have the likes of Wheeljack, Jazz, Starscream, and Soundwave at your command, but also a host of lesser known Transformers, including Tracks and Reflector, as well as cards for human allies and unforeseen events.

So what are you waiting for? "Transform and roll out!"

Name: Endicott Epidemic: The Board Game
Description:
Endicott Epidemic: The Board Game - an action-packed game of survival and Zombie combat.

Can your band of survivors escape the Zombie-infested village of Endicott before the town falls victim to an eradicating nuclear purge? Or will you become infected by the Undead and turn on your allies? The possibilities are endless in a game that utilizes randomization and custom structure mechanics that immerse players in a completely fresh scenario with every new round of play.

Based on the ENDICOTT EPIDEMIC multi-media series created by filmmaker and author Douglas Harvey, Endicott Epidemic: The Board Game is the first full board game that accompanies the Endicott Epidemic: Infectious Contagion card game.  While Infectious Contagion was the condensed, "lite" version of the main game, EE:TBG is an epic battle for survival that offers all of the insane mechanics and suspenseful buildup to destruction that the card game couldn't bring to the table (literally).

Utilizing game boards acting as maps based on primary areas of the Endicott Epidemic story (with fully functional expansion "connections" to mix and match your favorite ares as the game expands), players will drop their chosen characters (each with their own unique abilities that can be used strategically) into the heart of the epidemic and begin battling the Undead using classic roll-and-move mechanics as well as a series of unique "Intrique" cubes that modify gameplay with every roll.  A deck of Inquest cards act as side-missions that can be ignored or completed to gain resources used to fight and survive, or to gain special tokens that can be used in many different combinations to unlock new areas of play as the game progresses.

Combat is as simple as choosing your weapon (or brawling unarmed, if you so choose) and rolling the Combat Cubes.  Each face of each cube means a different value, giving you numerous combinations of attack to dish out against your chosen enemy.  But while rolling the cubes is the simple part, bear in mind that your enemies can (and most of the time *will*) fight back or dodge your attack entirely.  Strategize your plan of action before engaging the enemy to give you the best course through the hordes of Undead.  Or, if you think you have the stealth abilities to do so, roll the dice to try to evade the groups of enemies and slip through unnoticed and live to fight another turn.

But beware - hidden with the game's deck of cards lay numerous deadly obstacles ranging from stronger than average 'Boss' Zombies, Black Ops agents, and even a handful of mutant Hazard Zombies, which spread MBI's toxic plume everywhere they go.  Once these villains begin to appear, the spreading plume is something the Survivors must be extremely wary of.  Plume markers begin to build in each area and once they reach their critical mass, deadly chain reactions are caused that could potentially wipe out every living thing on the board.  The biggest and most brutal enemy within the deck, however, is the Countdown - eight cards that constantly remind players of the impending nuclear purge.  Once the eighth and final card is drawn, the game is over - regardless of whether or not the survivors have completed their mission to find the Hermit, his critical intel, and his escape route.

With all of the chaos going on as each Survivor makes their way through the town to complete their mission, the gameplay could get a little too intense for some people's liking.  Endicott Epidemic: The Board Game utilizes a completely customizable experience so that players can create the best scenario that is tailored to how they want to enjoy their game.  Removing certain aspects of the game like Hazard Zombies or Plume counters can greatly reduce the amount of suspenseful buildup that could turn players off from a game that could potentially be nearly impossible to win.  Inventory management and play deck building are also ways a group of players can ease the difficulty and ensure that the game, if played with all the right moves and strategic plans, can indeed be won without laying at the mercy of the Countdown or the roll of a die.

The board game, at its core, is designed for 2-8 players.  However, like Infectious Contagion, the board game also allows a single player to enjoy the game experience as the lone survivor of Endicott’s shift from living to undead.  Other game modes include a point-based Survivor mode that removes the Countdown and many other aspects of the game to allow players (or factions/teams of players) to battle waves of Undead, tallying up points at the end of each round and crowning a winner after a set amount of battles.  Or, players (or teams) can simply battle each other without the inclusion of Zombies (but with a Countdown) in a vastly customizable VS mode.

A ticking time-bomb's clock, swarms of Undead that will chain themselves together to create deadly hordes, an ever-spreading toxic plume beneath your feet, stealthy Black Ops agents that mark you for execution when you fall within their sights, a limited number of resources that must be used in conjunction with an even more limited inventory system, a constant surge of adrenaline with every roll of the Intrigue cubes, making allies with your fellow Survivors only to find your group surrounded by Zombies with only two bullets and a grenade...all of this and more is what builds your game up from a simple beginning to an all-out epic battle for survival.  Think you can handle it?

Name: Cosmic Odyssey
Description:
Join the Exploration League of Humanity (ELH) for a thrilling exploration of the galaxy.  Discover new planets, moons, and space stations as the most technologically advanced exploration carrier of the ELH, the Arcturus, travels from star system to star system.

Each planet the Arcturus travels to plays out as a round where only one card may be played per player.  Earn exploration credits by contributing the most to exploring the planet or give yourself an edge by upgrading your starship with new weapons and systems.  You can even become the ambassador to foreign space stations, helping you build even better starships to captain.

At the end of the game, the player with the most exploration credits wins the game.

Name: Splice
Description:
Splice is an evolution of Spline that can be played with a Series: Shibumi set, as it uses a 4x4 holes board and balls in three colours (white, black and red).

Start: The board starts empty.

Play: Players take turns placing either:

1) a ball of their colour on any hole or any platform that contains
at least one red ball, or

2) a red ball on any hole or any platform.

End: A player wins by making a flat line spanning side to side, or
corner to corner, on any level, composed entirely of friendly and
neutral balls (at least one of each).

If the placement of a red ball achieves this for both players, then
the mover wins.

Strategy: White should place at least one red ball on the board level,
otherwise Black can force a win due to parity. White should defend
this red ball so that Black can’t exploit it.

Name: Spoing
Description:
Spoing is a capture game that can be played with a Series: Shibumi set , as it uses a 4x4 holes board and balls in three colours (white, black and red).

Setup:

Place 8 black balls and 8 white balls according to this figure. Red balls are considered ‘neutral’:

â— â— â— â—
â— â— â— â—
â—‹ â—‹ â—‹ â—‹
â—‹ â—‹ â—‹ â—‹

Rules:

Two players, White and Black, alternate turns moving a ball of their colour or a neutral ball (red) to jump over a single ball of another colour and land on any ball to capture it. Jumps may be diagonal (as per Checkers) or orthogonal. Players must capture a ball each turn.
The ball landed on is removed and the ball jumped over is converted to the colour that is not the jumper or the jumpee, e.g. if the jumper is a white ball and the jumpee is a black ball then the jumpee gets replaced with a neutral ball (red).

The game ends immediately when a player can't move on their turn (which could happen if there are not three balls in a row somewhere, or if all remaining triples are unusable by the player). The winner is the player with the most balls of their colour on the board.

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-andres/shibumi-rule-book/paperback/product-18940123.html

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf

Name: Sphex
Description:
Sphex is a connection game that can be played with a Series: Shibumi set, as it uses a 4x4 holes board and balls in two colours (white and black).

Rules: The board starts empty. The opening player places one ball of their colour, then players take turns placing two balls of their colour on legal positions (holes or platforms). The mover can additionally place a neutral ball on their turn, in any order.

Aim: A player wins by connecting any two opposite sides of the board level with a chain of their balls. Balls connect if they touch, i.e. orthogonally adjacent or resting upon each other.

Name: One Two Three Quiz
Description:
A simple trivia party game.
12 sheets of different questions are provided. During a pause at your party, you can hold an imprompu quiz. The winner is the one who gets the most right answers

Name: Find the Mistakes
Description:
Party game. There are 15 sheets, with three pictures on each sheet. Guests are given a sheet each and, during the evening, must study the pictures and make a list of all the things wrong with each picture. For instance, a man might be holding an unopened umbrella but he is holding the umbrelly upside down.

The guest with the most correct observations wins.

Name: Forfeits
Description: Party game. Players are asked trivia questions to score points but if they get an answer wrong, they must do a forfeit. The one who avoids the most forfeits, wins

Name: Doubles
Description: Party game. Each guest is handed a picture. As they mingle during the evening, they try to match their picture. The first to be successful, wins.

Name: Errand Time
Description: Children's party game. Each child is given a shopping list and an article card. The object is that each child will ask other guests what their article is. If that article is on their shopping list, then they can mark it off. First to complete their shopping list, wins

Name: Number Please
Description:
Party Game. Guests are given a card. During the evening, you will be given clues by other guests as to the telephone number you are trying to find. The first guest to guess their telephone number correctly, wins
(By the way, in the 50's you didn't just have a number, you have a place-name that comes before the number e.g. Maida Vale 1234 would be a possible number).

Name: Foundations
Description:
Foundations is a 2 players abstract strategy game that is played using board and pieces of an Isaac set.

The aim of the game is getting rid of the value of your pieces by carefully placing them on the board or on already played pieces, thus creating a tridimensional structure developed on different levels.

Players take turns placing one of their pieces in ascending order of length. If they can't find space for a piece, they must build on the next level in height so that both ends of the piece rest on top of two pieces of its same colour.

When players are forced to build on new levels, they can begin with a smaller piece, but they must then play again in ascending order of length and they cannot play in lower levels anymore.

The game ends when players cannot place any more pieces on the board. The winner is the player with less points still in hand. In case of a tie, the winner is the player with less points at the highest level on the board.

Name: Playmates
Description:
Children's party game.
Each child is given an answer sheet and must try to find out the ages of the other guests. This encourages social skills as you probe for answers. The first to complete their record sheet, wins.

Name: Split Wits
Description:
Two party games in one box.
The first. Each guest gets half a head picture and must find their other half to make a complete head. First to do so, wins
The second. Each guest is given a card with a word on it. They must then find another guest's word that will form a correct longer word when you link the two words together. First to do so, wins.

Name: Hari
Description:
Hari is a 2 players abstract strategy game that is played using board and pieces of an Isaac set.

Players take turns sliding, discarding and placing their pieces in order to have the most points on the board.

Pieces must be used in ascending order of length and sacrifice short pieces to make room for longer ones is often required to achieve victory.

Name: Pussy
Description: Action game. The cat board has two holes, one worth 2 points, the other 4 points. Players take turns in trying to throw a ball into the cat's mouth. If you are successful, you score the points depending on which hole the ball comes out from. The one who scores the most points, wins.

Name: War Planes A Card Game for Aircraft Spotters
Description:
A box of Second World War aircraft identification cards titled 'War Planes - A Card Game for Aircraft Spotters'. The game was a Quartet game but with the unusual difference that the sets were not equal. The thrifty government, at the outbreak of war, ensured that players could also use the cards for regular card games by taking out the extra suit of 13 cards.
The pack comprises of 67 cards organised as follows:
65 illustrated cards representing five different views each of thirteen British and German aircraft, and two 'Key' cards.

It was intended that Spotters, at airfields or on the roofs of London buildings, could practice recognising aircraft to improve their skills.

Name: Matchomino
Description:
Contents: 90 square cards, cardboard stands, score pad & pencil

Each player receives 7 tiles. The remaining tiles form the face-down draw pile. One tile is turned face up, and the start player tries to match a tile from their hand to the face-up tile so that one edge matches. The next player then tries to match one or more edges etc. Black is a blocking colour and cannot be matched.

If a player manages to make a  match, the score is the sum of the printed-on values of the tile they placed plus those of the tiles that this tile now is adjacent to. Some tiles have stars, these double the value of the edge that the edge showing the star is matched with.

If a player cannot match a tile on their turn, they draw another tile and game continues with the next player.

Once one player runs out of tiles, all other players get one more turn after which the values of their remaining tiles are deducted from their scores. Highest score wins.

Name: Nochtschicht
Description:
The players represent members of a band. After a concert, they try to spend their whole salary from the gig. The goal of the game is to spend all your earned money, accumulate 8 hours of time cards, and go to your apartment.

The game is played by moving your pawn over a mapboard, showing the city of Vienna, overlayed with a grid. On your turn, you may move your pawn one or two spaces by foot, or three or four spaces by taxi, the latter costs money. You try to visit event locations (like Rosie's Café, your band's rehearsal room, a hot dog booth and various others). On most spaces you have to draw cards, which will help you to spend money and acquire time cards.

The trick is to keep the right balance between spending money and acquiring time cards. You need at least 8 hours worth of time cards, then you can try to get to your apartment and win the game - but only if you have no money left.

This game's pawns represent members of a locally known band in Austria; the title is Viennese slang and translates to "night shift".

Name: Pitzelpatz Geburtstags-Party
Description: Its Pitzelpatz (a teddy bear) birthday! You want all 6 guests to come. For this 2 players each get a house and then try to use the colour die to pick the appropriately coloured guest. The first one to roll all 6 colours and thus get all 6 guests to his house wins.

Name: 5150: Star Army
Description:
5150: Star Army is a rewrite and update of the military and bugs sections of the original 5150.

This game has a strong focus on military skirmishes of up to about a company, with a platoon being more typical.  Each figure represents one man, alien or vehicle.  There are three basic scenarios- patrol, attack and defend, which are each altered by a system for randomly laying out the board as well as generating opposing forces for solo players.  Individual games can combine in a campaign where individual soldiers improve over time and new recruits might become available.

Name: Machine of Death
Description:
A 50 card deck of death predictions: ways in which people can die.

Rather than being a game in itself, the cards are a game system: they are used to create and play other games, or optionally supplement other existing games. The cards come with rules for games with players being encouraged to create their own.

The cards feature a single word or phrase detailing how a person can die: for instance, OLD AGE or TRAGIC FLAW or FED UP BARISTA. These predictions can be used in party games ala Apples to Apples: one player names a weapon and the rest submit a card from their hand that they feel could have been given to a person killed with that weapon. They can be used in storytelling games, where each player gets a card and the group must construct a series of events in which everyone dies. The rules also include an RPG of sorts, where players must buy items to kill targets with the deaths dealt from the deck.

Name: Spao
Description:
Spao is a 3-player ball-stacking game that can be played with a Series: Shibumi set. It uses a '4x4 holes board' and balls in 3 colours.

Each player has an allocated colour (white, black and red). Players take turns placing a ball of their colour in a legal position (hole or 2x2 platform). When the pyramid is full the game ends. To get your score multiply the sizes of your groups. Highest score wins.

Variant for 2 players:

Red balls are neutral. Each player takes 10 balls of his colour (white or black) and 5 red balls. On your turn you place one of your balls in a legal position. Same scoring.

Rules for this game are included in the soft cover Shibumi Rule Book

Name: Slalom
Description:
At the starting gate the tension is very high, the  snow is perfect, the atmosphere is the one of the big occasion. In an explosion of force, power and technique you face the first run of the giant slalom during the first meeting of the white circus.
You are one of last season's best skiers and lots of fans are expecting a great result from you and you cannot disappoint them. You will count on your incredible talent, your explosive strength, your cold lucidity. As cool calculator you will fight against all the hazards of the track to the best of your abilities.
Win the race and be on the cover of the most famous sporting magazines of the world.

Slalom is a game for 2 to 4 players (the single descents serve only for training). The competition is divided in 2 runs where every skier in turn tries to descend in quickest possible time to complete the slalom. The skier will move on the 14 tiles, using the values of the card they received at the start and at the two intermediate times.
Every move on the race tiles will be followed by a positive or a negative change of the starting time.
The hourglass will force the players to organize the sequence of their plays in the available time, in order not to lose precious hundredths of second.
The cowbell represents the support of the people near the track and it will help the skiers during the critical moments of the race...

Name: Obama / Nobama
Description: A trick-taking game centered around US politics.  Each card represents a controversial and/or humorous issue being discussed on 24-hour news stations, and tricks represent gathering the most viewers (via making the most controversial statements) at different time slots.  Instead of conventional bidding, players select their true party (hidden) and their apparent party (visible).  Each party offers different scoring incentives and different special powers, and players sometimes have the option to switch parties.

Name: StrikerZ Card Game
Description:
StrikerZ Card Game Description:
 StrikerZ Card Game is a fantastic football game with cards! It is not a game "about" football. It IS football! Players pick and discard through a full deck as they try to get one of the three combinations to shoot for a goal! Each team has 11 players, 3 super-subs and a manager! Enjoy light and fun strategy as the shooter and keeper try to outsmart each other on shot attempts: Big Goals! Big Saves!
 Do you think that you will manage your team to easy victory? Will the referee and assistants influence the game for you or against you? Watch out as there are whistles, offsides, yellow cards and red card ejections! Either manager can make a key substitution at the right time to change the game! A game of skill and luck!
 This is an excellent game for football fanatics, couples, or children.

For 2 players, Ages 7 to Adult, 30 minute time frame.

Name: Agricola: De Lage Landen
Description:
Agricola: De Lage Landen is an expansion for Agricola that is published by the Dutch game company 999 Games. It combines certain decks previously released separately in other languages, as well as some new decks.

The expansion is divided in 3 decks (240 cards in total):
- Netherlands-deck (NL-Deck)
- Flanders-deck (FL-Deck)
- Wallonia-deck (WA-Deck)

Next to this, it also contains:
- Agricola: Through the Seasons
- Stylized grain and vegetables resource pieces (to replace the standard resource discs)
- Sticker sheet

Name: Little England
Description:
The Kingdom is united no more! Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have risen up to invade their historical oppressor! 2-4 players take the role of the four countries as they carve up England for their own glory.
Primarily card-driven, players will play attack cards to cities of different strengths (including bluff cards) to wrestle control of the cities away from their opponents. However if more than two countries turn up for a fight, politics and alliances intervene as players make simple deals with those in the battle.
Every time a city is captured, the final points value of the city drops. After five rounds of play the country with the most control points is the victor.
Little England is a free print and play game requiring only five pages for the game (four double-sided) and one double-sided sheet for the rules.

Name: Know Your Bible
Description: Card game with trivia questions about the Bible. It also has rules for a Biblical Patience game using the cards.

Name: The Pigeon Wants a Match
Description:
First the Pigeon wanted to drive a bus. Then the Pigeon found a hot dog. Now the Pigeon wants a match in this new game from University Games. Based on the Pigeon book series by Mo Willems, The Pigeon Wants a Match Game finds players trying to collect the most matches of hilarious images from the books. Color-coded borders and backgrounds make pairing tiles easy and fun for even the youngest matchers. The game is designed to help develop visual literacy and coordination skills. This game brings the fun of the books to kids in a new way.

The difference between The Pigeon Wants a Match and Memory is that The Pigeon Wants a Match has a tile that will allow you to gain an extra turn and one that will force you to lose a turn if you turn over a certain tile.

Name: Space Ludo
Description:
From the Publisher's website:
Space Ludo is a space sci fi themed version of Ludo, a traditional race and capture game enjoyed around the world. Ludo is related to Pachisi, Trouble, Sorry! and others. All of them are simplified descendants of the ancient Indian cross and circle game, Pachisi.

Space Ludo offers an addicting blend of luck and strategy. Dice are involved yet crucial choices occur frequently. The rules are simple yet the game is always interesting and pleasant to replay. Such are the hallmarks of a classic and so, Ludo has stood the test of time.

Space Ludo utilizes the standard, widely known Ludo rules. These comprise the foundation of play and will be familiar to long time players. New players are encouraged to play the standard game first.

Space Ludo adds the deathmatch element, wormholes and other optional rules to expand and enhance the game.

The theme of Space Ludo comes from the spaced-out universe of the indie computer games Strange Adventures in Infinite Space (2002) and Weird Worlds: Return to Infinite Space (2005).

Name: The Great War: Over the Top
Description: Over the Top contains a full year-by-year overview of the 1915-18 period, new Battalion-level army lists for British Empire, French and German forces, and a new army list for the American Expeditionary Force, including the Devil Dogs and US Tank Companies. It also contains detailed rules covering such actions as assaulting a trench line, or leading a hand-picked party on a trench raid, as well as background missions to set miniature wargames within the larger backdrop of some of the greatest actions of the First World War.

Name: Outlines
Description: One player draws a card and describes the shown image to the other players who are simultaneously drawing what is described. The images are generally geometric shapes. After 1 minute the drawers judge their image against the original and receive 1 point if it matches. First player to 15 points wins.

Name: Word Scramble
Description:
Word Scramble bills itself as a "phonological awareness and word-building game".  Tiles are used to make words in the middle of playing board.

Based on the squares on which their pawns land, players either blindly draw a tile, move a tile already on the board or read all the words on the board.  Five board spaces direct the player to draw a tile give them the choice between the word beginning or ending piles.  Nineteen spaces specify from which pile the player should draw.  Those spaces also direct the player to define the word played, rhyme it, use it in a sentence or use it in a question.  Four spaces direct the player to read all the words already on the board, awarding four points for doing so.  Landing on one of the four corners allows the player to move a tile already on the board.

Tiles drawn or moved are placed on one of 61 spaces in the middle of the board which have either word beginnings or endings.  Harder-to-match tiles or spaces are worth more points than easy ones.  Points values range from one to six.  Play ends after one player reaches a predetermined number of points.

Name: Taxifahrer
Description:
Players represent taxi drivers and have to drive passengers through the city, earning money.

Every player starts with a passenger card, which gives him an address where to pick up a passenger, and a destination, where that passenger wants to go. He then rolls the dice and moves his taxi on the mapboard to the given locations. On grey colored spaces, he has to discard one of his four petrol cans; if he discards the last, it's time to visit the petrol station for refuelling. On his moves, a player has to obey all traffic regulations like road signs, speed limits, pedestrian crossings, and so on. If he violates a rule, any other player may point that out and the offender has to pay him a fine of 20.

After bringing a passenger to his destination, the player gets payed and draws another passenger card.

The taxi driver who first collects the sum of 400 fares wins the game.

Name: Acchiappa il Fantasma!
Description: Casper the ghost is the star of this game where two teams must to hide their 10 ghosts. Each turn the players will choose an object of the other team hoping to find a ghost. The winner will be the team who will find all the ghosts of the opponent.
Families: TV Shows: Casper the Friendly Ghost

Name: International Road Racing
Description:
A replay game of grand prix motor cycle racing.

Players control all motorcycles in a motor cycle grand prix race. The game includes statistical data for every circuit raced in 1984, and for all classes of motorcycles, like 80, 125, 250, 500c.c. as well as sidecars.

After you have decided which race to run, you set up all the drivers (represented by cardboard figures). For every racer you turn up a card from a deck of race cards and compare the individual driver's rating with a table printed on each card. The card now tells you if the racers stay in the group of motorcycles they are currently in, if they fall back to the previous group, overtake other drivers within their group, or even catch up with the group in front of them. Mechanical troubles as well as possible accidents are also covered by the results of the card.

After a number of draws, depending on the racing course and class of motorcycles chosen, the race is over.

The game lets you replay any single race from the 1984 season or even the whole championship.

Name: International Road Racing 1987 Up-Dates
Description:
An expansion for International Road Racing that uses statistical data to recreate individual races or the whole championship of the Grand Prix motor cycle 1987 season.

The game also includes optional rules for positioning individual racers within a group.

Name: International Road Racing 1988 Up-Dates
Description: An expansion for International Road Racing that uses statistical data to recreate individual races or the whole championship of the Grand Prix motor cycle 1988 season.

Name: Ice Racing
Description:
Ice Racing is an expansion set that lets you recreate the Ice Speedway world championship finals from the years 1983 to 1991.

The expansion consists of a data sheet for each year and a new set of trouble and injury charts representing the different hazards for ice speedway.

Name: Kasse-Gasse
Description:
Kasse-Gasse is played with a deck of 36 cards and a die. Each card shows a word from which one letter is missing. The die shows six letters: b, d, g, k, p and t (the 'plosives').

At the start of the game, the cards are shuffled, and eight cards are drawn and placed on the table, face-up. Then, the die is rolled. All players now search for a word on one of the cards that can be completed with the letter rolled. The first player that finds such a card and pronounces the word correctly gets to keep the card.

Then, a new card is drawn and the next round starts. At the end of the game, the player who has collected the most cards wins.

Name: Chi?
Description:
Italian board game of the '70, based on the TV show "Chi?".
Each game consists of 4 rounds: memory test, ability, identikit and crime fiction.

In the first round (memory test), the player who plays the host role (or presenter) shows an image, to each player, for a very short time (10 seconds). Each player, then, must answer to the questions and remember the details.
In the second round, ability, the players, to gain the priority to answer, must to insert quick as possible a colored ball into a "tower" selector.
The "Identikit" is a character hunt.
Last round is the crime fiction. Who is playing the host role selects 3 cards, one for each deck: "chi" (who), "dove" (where) and "che cosa" (what). The players must to use clues to find the solution.

At the end, the player who scores more points is the winner.

Name: Hell on the Margin
Description:
Generic Sci-Fi wargame aimed at divisional level forces and playable in an evening.
Figures are mounted on bases that represent platoons and are activated by a command point system resulting in a simple and quick flowing game concentrating on high level tactics rather than individual weapon stats.
Rules and organization tables are included for two human and two alien forces models for which were available from Irregular Miniatures in the UK.

Name: Bournville Cocoa
Description:
Cadbury placed this game into a children's Christmas annual, called Chick's Own, in 1952, as an advertisement for their hot cocoa drink.
Any number can play. Give each player a piece of paper and get them to write down Cadburys Bournville Cocoa on it.
The idea of the game is to collect all the letters that spell Cadburys Bournville Cocoa. Almost every square on the board has a letter, so if you arrive on a square you can tick off that letter from the name on your paper.
You need a 6 to start (of course!).
If you land on a square with special instructions, you must obey them.
The first player to tick off all their letters, wins. And the rules say you should get a steaming cup of lovely chocolately Bournville Cocoa.

Name: The Conflict
Description:
The Great War (1914)

It is the summer of 1914. The Archduke Franz Ferdinand (heir to the throne of the Austro-Hungarian Empire) and his wife have just been assassinated in Sarajevo. In retaliation for this offense, Emperor Franz Joseph of Austria-Hungary has declared war on Serbia, an ally of Russia. This sparks a world of controversy and very quickly large military powers such as Germany, The Ottoman Empire, France, and Great Britain join in the fray. Two allegiances emerge, The Central Powers & The Allied Powers, with one goal in mind: WAR!

Do you have the economic aptitude and tactical know how to help your nation survive The Conflict and rescue a world in peril. Are you brave enough to face tanks, planes and other modern warfare in order to lead your alliance to victory? “The Great War” has begun, and ready or not, you better lace up your boots and prepare for battle.

The Conflict is a global-strategy based game designed around the economic and military conditions of Europe in 1914. Players play in one of two alliances, The Central Powers or The Allied Powers, to defeat their opponents. Players choose among seven nations (Austria-Hungary, Germany, Great Britain, France, Italy, Ottoman Empire, and Russia). After selecting a nation, players take turns completing their objectives during each round.

Note: The Conflict requires players to strategize both economically and militaristically in order to win the game.

Note: Military units will vary per nation, based on the technological restraints of the nation and its overall capability for growth.

Planned release date is 2012.

Name: The Last Edda
Description:
The great World Tree is rotting...

The forces of Asgard and Vanaheim have turned against one another.  The minions of Jotunheim and Svartalfheim have gone insane.  Diseased, toxic creatures spew forth into Midgard, and the gods, once protectors of that land, have forsaken humankind in their blind rage against one another.  Once their sacred protectorate, Midgard is now their battleground.

In The Last Edda, players take on the role of one of six Norse gods and do battle, taking control of the monstrosities pouring out of the tainted Yggdrasil, in order to defeat their rival.

The Last Edda blends the mechanics of player combat and deck building card games.  Each turn, a player has the option of directing monsters from a common pool at his opponent, while his opponent has the opportunity to defend the attack by playing unit cards from his hand.  The turn also provides an opportunity for players to buy cards from personal and common supplies, and construct buildings and artifacts that remain in play and help you to defend and attack more effectively.

Yggdrasil, the World Tree is rotting.  The air grows colder and drier by the day.  Murmurs of Fimbulvetr and Ragnarok can be heard across Midgard.  Which of the gods is strong enough to survive the coming storm?

Name: Race Thru Space
Description: A game published by Ovaltine, presumeably a free giveaway to advertise their beverage. It is a simple roll and move game through the solar system.First to finish, wins.

Name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Control Room Promo
Description:
Promo given to stores for Ascension game days around September 21, 2011.

Control Room

Cost: 5 Runes

Mechana Construct

Once per turn, you may put a Mechana Construct you control on top of the center deck.  If you do, acquire a Mechana Construct in the center row and put it in your hand.

5 Honor

Name: Brer-Rabbit Ring a Bunny
Description: The target for this Hoop-La type game is a rabbit with large ears, eating a carrot. Players take turns to try to throw their three wooden rings over the rabbit's ears. The player who has the most successes wins the game.

Name: Caperucita Roja
Description:
In the box:
Who will be the first to fill her basket to Grandmother? But be careful with the wolf! A game full of surprises tour based on the famous story of "Little Red Riding Hood".

System:
The goal is to bring grandma flowers, honey and bread. Once inside the cabin with some of the gifts you have to turn the figure of Little Red Riding Hood. Grandma's bed has a mechanism that makes the wolf in granny "wake up" some times when you turn the figure of Little Red Riding Hood and the player must play must start from the beginning.

The way to get to Grandma's is a clue boxes free of obstacles.


De la caja:
¿Quién será el primero en llenar su cestita a la Abuelita? ¡Pero mucho cuidado con el lobo!
Un juego de recorrido lleno de sorpresas basado en el célebre cuento de "La Caperucita Roja".

Sistema de juego:
El objetivo del juego es llevar a la abuelita flores, miel y pan. Una vez dentro de la cabaña con alguno de los regalos, hay que girar la figura de Caperucita Roja. La cama de la abuelita dispone de un mecanismo que hace que el lobo disfrazado de abuelita "despierte" algunas veces en las que se gira la figura de Caperucita y el jugador debe jugador debe empezar desde el principio.

El camino para llegar a la casa de la abuelita es una pista de casillas libre de obstáculos.
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: Little Red Riding Hood

Name: Guild Quest
Description: Guild Quest tells the story of the last great quest ordered by the king of Hawksvale. Each turn, a player will have the choice to either pursue the quest, or find an inn or tavern to recruit more heros. Quest cards describe an obstacle your guild of adventurers must overcome or even a raid against another player. Battles are resolved by placing heros in a strategic formation and activating simultaneously their combat skills depending on their position in the formation.

Name: Wanted
Description:
Objective: Score points by drawing faces, which match most - compared with the one shown to the players earlier

out of the rules: "Look and remember" 
1. for a certain (short) time each player is shown a face simultaniously.
2. Using a pencil and a stencil each player draws a face during an agreed short time with at many details (up to 20) he/she can remember
3. Each player gains points: no difference 10 p., 1 diff. 5 p...
4. Game ends after a previously arranged no of rounds/time

The game was invented and designed by Ora & Theo Coster - Theora Design

Name: Tornisto
Description: Tornisto is an abstract strategy game for two to four players where each player attempts to move all five of his towers to the opposite side of the board.  The towers vary in height and can jump over any tower that is shorter than itself.

Name: Tidley Skittles
Description:
Early British game using Tiddlywinks' counters.
The board is placed in the centre of the table. On the board are placed a set of small wooden skittles. The object is to knock over skittles using your counters Tiddlywink fashion. If you do knock over a skittle, you score points depending on where it was standing.
The box image illustrates the game rather well

Name: Spight
Description:
Spight is a ball stacking and connection game that can be played with a Series: Shibumi set. It uses a board of 4x4 holes, 8 white balls and 8 black balls.

Setup:

Place 8 black balls and 8 white balls according to the figure.

â— â—‹ â— â—‹
â—‹ â— â—‹ â—
â— â—‹ â— â—‹
â—‹ â— â—‹ â—

Rules:

Two players, White and Black, alternate turns moving a ball of their colour either:

a) jumping like a chess knight from a hole to another empty hole or...
b) jumping up from a hole to an adjacent 2x2 platform or...
c) passing if there are no available moves.

Notice that other balls may drop as a result.

Aim:

Win by connecting all your pieces into a single group.

Rules for this game are included in the soft cover Shibumi Rule Book

Name: 25 New Games to be Played with Lexicon Cards
Description:
A book of variants for the game Lexicon, published by Waddingtons in 1935 or so. They had had great success with selling the original game, so they decided the market would like more variety. In effect, in modern terms, this book is an expansion as it adds lots of new rules that will need different strategy.

The 64-page booklet sold separately (red cover for one shilling) and advertised 25 variants. The pale blue/green version was included for free in first edition blue books sold in 1935, but has rules for only 23 variant games with the Lexicon deck: Bridge; Whist; Scramble; Dominoes; Cribbage; Poker; Stud Poker; Eights; Clock Patience; Brighton Patience; Dictionary; Riddance; Donkey; Criss Cross; Twister; One Better; Jumble; Tap and Grab; Mine; Don't Forget; Demon; Pay Up; and Teasers. (The red cover edition also includes Lexicon Newmarket and Lexicon Duplexicon.)

Name: Memoir '44: Campaign Book Volume 2
Description:
Memoir '44: Campaign Book Volume 2, the second hardcover supplement for the Memoir '44 game system, contains 46 new scenarios and builds upon the campaign rules introduced in Campaign Book Volume 1 to let players experience scenarios in succession, with the outcome of each battle impacting the next.

These 46 scenarios are grouped into eleven different campaigns, with two set in the Pacific Theater – "Island Hoppers", a Grand Campaign covering the progressive re-conquest of the Pacific by the Allied forces following the attack on Pearl Harbor, and "Bicycle Blitzkrieg", the Japanese invasion of Malaya in 1941-1942 – and the first Breakthrough campaign for Memoir '44: "Breakthrough Normandy", covering the Allied offensive in Normandy from D-Day through August 1944.

Two other campaigns – "Fall of Poland", depicting the desperate resistance of Polish forces against the German Blitzkrieg of September 1939, and "Air Aces", a campaign following the exploits of famous air aces throughout World War II – round up the Theaters of Operations covered in the book.

Memoir '44: Campaign Book Volume 2 comes with a punchboard containing fifty game tokens and requires the Memoir '44 base game as well as theater-specific expansions for some of the campaigns, specifically Memoir '44: Pacific Theater, Memoir '44: Air Pack, Memoir '44: Terrain Pack and Memoir '44: Breakthrough.

Name: Auf zum Sachsenring
Description:
Objective: be the first to reach the target (field 1)
‘Roll and Move’ game
Equipment: board, 6 meeples, 3 dice
1. Start positions are to be filled (use one die by turns – 3 turns max) – ‘1’ allows you to place your meeple onto the board
2. Race: use 3 dice - standard speed ïƒ¨  3; gaining a double ïƒ¨ 6; a triple ïƒ¨ 9. Per die-roll of a ‘6’ one additional space, so that a triple ‘6’ let you move 12 spaces forward 
3. Events (brown marked) on the board may accelerate or decelerate or block you

Rules state that number of participants is not limited
